comments.body:
This was actually changed in the prototype branch by @densh.

Keeping `scala.Boolean` results in:
```
[error] Error while emitting Boolean.scala
[error] assertion failed:
[error]   expected class type in classOf[T], found primitive type Z
[error]      while compiling: /Users/ergys/dev/scala/native/javalib/src/main/scala/java/lang/Boolean.scala
[error]         during phase: jvm
[error]      library version: version 2.12.12
[error]     compiler version: version 2.12.12
[error]   reconstructed args: ...
[error]
[error]   last tree to typer: TypeTree(class Array)
[error]        tree position: line 78 of /Users/ergys/dev/scala/native/javalib/src/main/scala/java/io/DataOutputStream.scala
[error]             tree tpe: Array[Byte]
[error]               symbol: final class Array in package scala
[error]    symbol definition: final class Array[T] extends Object (a ClassSymbol)
[error]       symbol package: scala
[error]        symbol owners: class Array
[error]            call site: constructor UnixPath$$anon$1 in package fs

```

Is that only broken in the javalib, or would user code be affected by this problem as well? I.e., would a test in unit-tests that uses `classOf[scala.Byte]` be broken or not? If user code is broken, we should fix it somehow.
In `sandbox`, `classOf[scala.Boolean]` prints `class scala.scalanative.runtime.PrimitiveBoolean`, so I guess it's OK.

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +45,49 @@object Boolean {
  final val TYPE =
    scala.Predef.classOf[scala.scalanative.runtime.PrimitiveBoolean]
  final val TRUE: Boolean  = new Boolean(true)
  final val FALSE: Boolean = new Boolean(false)
